articleBody: Learning Objectives â€¢ Understand the role of colour contrast in enhancing visual appeal. â€¢ Identify and apply complementary colours to create dynamic compositions. â€¢ Experiment with tonal contrast to shape mood and depth in photographs. Learn More & Join Download Assignment PDF Before You Shoot â€¢ Choose a location with varied colours and lighting conditions. â€¢ Gather a selection of objects or subjects that showcase different colours. â€¢ Set your camera to either aperture priority or shutter priority mode. â€¢ Fix your ISO at 200 to maintain consistent exposure. â€¢ Prepare to experiment with both warm and cool colour palettes. The Assignment Technical Focus â€¢ Use aperture priority mode to control depth of field while focusing on contrasting colours. â€¢ Experiment with different focal lengths to see how colour contrast changes with perspective. â€¢ Pay attention to natural light and how it affects colour perception. â€¢ Utilize backlighting to enhance the vibrancy of colours in your subjects. â€¢ Incorporate textures to add another layer of contrast to your images. Creative Focus â€¢ Explore the use of complementary colours in your compositions for maximum impact. â€¢ Create a series of images that juxtapose warm and cool colours. â€¢ Look for opportunities to contrast soft and hard textures within your colour compositions. â€¢ Use colour to convey emotions; for example, use warm colours to evoke energy and cool colours for calmness. â€¢ Tell a story through colour by selecting subjects that represent different emotions or themes. Assignment Tasks â€¢ Photograph a scene using aperture priority mode at f/4, ISO 200 fixed, focusing on contrasting warm and cool colours. â€¢ Capture a close-up of an object with a vibrant colour against a neutral background using aperture priority mode at f/2.8, ISO 200 fixed. â€¢ Create a diptych showcasing two images: one with high tonal contrast and the other with low tonal contrast, both shot in aperture priority mode with ISO 200. â€¢ Shoot an outdoor scene in the golden hour, focusing on the warm colours of the sunset using shutter priority mode at 1/250s, ISO 200 fixed. â€¢ Experiment with shadows and highlights in a black and white scene to emphasize tonal contrast, using aperture priority mode at f/5.6, ISO 200 fixed. â€¢ Capture a portrait that employs a contrasting colour background to highlight the subjectâ€™s features, using aperture priority mode at f/3.5, ISO 200 fixed. ðŸ’¡ Stretch Tasks â€¢ Create a photo series that explores a single colour in various contexts and lighting conditions, using both aperture and shutter priority modes. â€¢ Develop a conceptual portrait project that tells a story through contrasting colours and tones, focusing on both emotional and physical contrasts. DO / DON'T DO â€¢ âœ“ Do experiment with different lighting conditions to see how they affect colour perception. â€¢ âœ“ Do pay attention to the background and its impact on the subject's colour. â€¢ âœ“ Do take multiple shots with varying colour contrasts to find the most effective composition. â€¢ âœ“ Do use editing software to enhance the colour contrast in your images post-shoot. â€¢ âœ“ Do practice shooting in different environments to gain a broader understanding of colour theory. DON'T â€¢ âœ— Don't use overly bright or saturated colours without considering their context. â€¢ âœ— Don't ignore the effect of shadows on your composition's colour balance. â€¢ âœ— Don't rely solely on post-processing to create colour contrast; focus on capturing it in-camera. â€¢ âœ— Don't use distracting elements that compete with your main subject's colour. â€¢ âœ— Don't forget to consider the emotional impact of the colours you choose to include.
